So in our district plan and most district plans at the moment,  There are generally rules that say if you want to develop something on a site, you have to have a minimum number of car parks. And the national direction now is that we must take those rules out of plans. Part of the rationale behind that is it's kind of a bit of a mixed bag. Part of it is around freeing up some really highly valuable urban land for development rather than use of car parks. text: So as part of this, and I didn't mention it yesterday, SPMP, Isla Jim, under the Resource Management Act, we were able to take financial contributions. So we have development contributions, which is what developers pay for future infrastructure. And then we have financial contributions, which is what land use and developers pay  for immediate impact, if that makes sense. The RMA was changed about seven or eight years ago to take those out under the national government, and the Labour government then repealed that change. So financial contributions are back in as of this year. In our district plan, we have Chapter 18, which means that we can impose financial contributions on resource consents that come through. And so what that allows us to do is put  the owners back on developers and applicants to help fund some of the council's infrastructure, if we can demonstrate their adverse effects. So this could be one real example where, and we can do that for offsite effects as well. It doesn't have to be related to the site. So our financial contributions could potentially allow us to require financial contributions for cycleways, if there's an impact on the road. So that's a really good question.

text: OK, so on to page 18, top of page 18. So Katarani will be well aware of this. So the government's also issued new national directions on September for national environmental standards and policy statements around freshwater management.  That primarily impacts the regional council. So Waikato Regional Council is, I guess, recipient of that to implement it. We've had a look at it and we don't think there's any direct impacts on Waipara District Council. There may be indirect ones whereby, for example, Waikato District Regional Council, if we are seeking discharge consents, tighten up some of the conditions around that. So that's something that we're still coming to grips with in terms of what it means. And we're talking with WRC colleagues around what they think it means.  There's two that the government has pushed back. So there's a National Policy Statement for Indigenous Biodiversity and there's a National Policy Statement for Highly Predicted Soils. Both of those have been deferred to around mid-2021, the Ministry have advised us. And the big one that you're probably all aware of is the RMA reform. So the Randerson report came out with some recommendations for quite extensive reform of the Resource Management Act.  The summary is all there on page 18, but it creates, if the recommendations go through, it would create three new acts. The RMA would be replaced by a Natural and Built Environments Act. The good news is, I guess, there'd be new environmental bottom lines. So across the country, we've seen various degrees of environmental management.  And so what would be established in the new Act if the recommendations went through would be hard bottom lines and the director of MFE talked about hard and tight bottom lines. So I think there's a real desire to actually put some bottom lines in. In terms of urban development, the intention there would be to do more planning up front and have less regulation through resource consent process. So we'd probably see better management of the natural resources and  simplified and streamlining of urban planning. There's a new Strategic Planning Act which would create mandatory spatial plans for the region, and we're actually well advanced in that here in the Waikato region with FutureProof. And there'll be a third new act called the Managed Retreat and Climate Change Adaption Act. And that would give councils some tools and set up a regime for better management of climate change  Mitigation as well as adaptation. And of interest to this group is also in the in the replacement to the RMA or actually separate. A recognition that there needs to be a better mechanism of iwi Māori involvement and decision making around planning. And so the recommendations set up a new national iwi advisory group.  to advise local government around iwi Māori perspectives, I guess, and increased participation. And the words that they use in the recommendation is mana whenua, so they've gone away from iwi authorities and they're starting to talk about mana whenua. So increased participation for mana whenua and RMA plans and spatial plans. So again, we're probably relatively well positioned in the Waikato and Waipa. Just look at this committee, for example, not all councils have committees like this.  and so we've probably got a bit of a lead on other councils around this, but we have some more tools that we'll be able to roll out if this all goes through. Talking to various colleagues and people and ministry officials, the feeling is that whichever party gets in after the elections will pick up the report and run with it. What we don't know is what recommendations they'll roll out and how fast they'll do it.  But everyone I've spoken to in the general consensus is. There's no desire to roll back and not do a reform, so it may happen quite quick, depend on the government appetite. They have talked about having the new acts in place in July 2022 as the recommendation, which is quite fast. But there will be a consultative process through that so.  I guess some anxiety around what it might look like, but probably some opportunities in there. And my thinking is quite an exciting time to be in this area, because there might be some really good outcomes that come out of this.
speaker: tonyquick

text: And a couple of the points that you've touched on there, I suppose, are the environmental concerns and then there's the cost side of things and affordability.  And I suppose and certainly the council hasn't discussed that, but there's no so there's no formal policy on it, but there is nothing to stop somebody wishing to put in a rainwater tank in the urban centre if they wish. So, if you put the environmental issues to one side,  the absolute cheapest water you're ever going to get is through the public supply. So if you're going to put in a new tank and a pump, and then I suppose if you're going to try and use it for all of your activities in the house, then you've got to put some treatment capacity in there as well, because the new drinking water standards are going to say everybody's got to have a potable water supply.  So if you're not going to put in treatment, then all you can use it for is your gardens or flushing toilets, et cetera, which means a duplicate plumbing system. So there are  quite significant additional costs if you want to run a duplicate system on a normal residential property. And by far the cheapest option is to use the public supply. And if everybody invested anything that they were intending to spend on their own home into the public supply, there would be absolutely no need for rainwater tanks.  From an environmental perspective, there's obviously some opportunities there for, I suppose, saving water. And from an individual perspective, there's some savings, particularly over the winter period when it's raining quite consistently and your tank is always full.  In the summer, when there's a public supply, we have to design from a council point of view, that system to cope with everybody who wants to draw down water. And after a period of two or three weeks of no rain, everybody wants water from the main. So, all of our design work has to make sure that the pipes are big enough to supply the water that everybody wants in a summer period.  So, effectively, what happens is people use the water for, if you want to call it free, in the wet weather. Come the summer, when there's a demand for it, all of their tanks are dry and they want to take it out of the public system. So, there's increased costs then because we've got to supply surplus capacity over the winter. So, it's quite a complex issue. And realistically, if the rain  falls on the roof and gets discharged into the Waikato catchment without going through a rainwater tank. It's the same volume of water that ends up in the catchment, whether it goes into a tank first and then onto the gardens, then into the catchment, as if it just flows straight into the Waikato catchment.  So, it's not a simple, let's put in tanks, everybody will save a bit of water and it'll have an impact on the environment either. So, yeah, I think it's a topic that needs a lot of debate before we go trying to get people to put in rainwater tanks on every house. A lot of them can't be retrofitted. There's not enough space on the section. The sections are getting smaller. You know, it is a difficult situation.
speaker: jimmylchreest

text: Thank you, Your Worship. Kia ora koutou, everybody. Good morning. So I'm the manager who has the joy of being responsible for dog control. So that's why I'm appearing before you today to present this report. So in opening, I'd just like to confirm that  The Strategic Planning and Policy Committee were made aware of this issue yesterday as well. So they are ready for any recommendations that may come from your committee going forward. So I'll take my report largely as read. Hopefully, it's provided a summary of the issues that have been raised with Council. And that's generally the question around whether the existing controls on Kakapuka and Maunga are appropriate.  But probably more importantly, whether the processes that led to those controls were correct or were followed and what we need to look at going forward to resolve this issue. So staff have taken quite an amount of time to explore the issues and the possible remedies that may exist in the space.  And where we've ended up is that the only real option is to look at Council's dog control policy, because that's where these controls come from. That's the source of where the dog prohibited, dog on lead areas come from. And at present, that policy isn't scheduled until 2025. So the committee, the Policy and Planning Committee will be looking for some direction on that timeframe and what may be needed through that process.  So if we go down that road, then the other part of it is that we want to make sure that we've captured any other sites that may be of concern or of interest as well. So we need to just be mindful that once the policy review starts, it's the full public consultation process that will open the door to everybody's ideas. We want to do so.  We want to do some work up front to make sure that any other areas are captured in this early stage. So I'm interested in some of Tony's comments there about how there's already a process of identifying some sites that may have interests or concerns, so we can have a look at that as well.  And the other aspect we have to consider is that we need to balance it with our statutory obligations under the Dial Control Act, as well as to why that policy is in place and what it requires Council to do and not to do. So that's really the quick summary. We want to resolve this matter going forward, but we just cannot identify any quick fix that's going to  to satisfy the concerns that have been raised. So obviously the process needs to start somewhere. So that's why we've brought this matter to this committee today. And yeah, be keen on your thoughts and feedback.

speaker: katarainahodge

text: So the Dog Control Act gives us three options. Either an area can be prohibited to dogs altogether. Dogs can be in an area, but they have to be on a lead, or they can be in an area that can be free roaming with dogs or for leads. So basically what the law says is that if a council doesn't make an area prohibited to dogs and it doesn't make it free  off-lead area for dogs, then by default, it becomes an area that's dog-on-lead. So this particular piece of land has been dog-on-lead because neither of those other two options have been applied.  So, so Catarina, it's complicated there because the reserve at the top, which is a Crown owned, I think it's an historic reserve, has always been dogs prohibited because it's a Department of Conservation reserve.

The first two, the vision and the community outcomes are kind of longer term tenure.  the longer term 10-year visions that we're trying to achieve, and then the priority areas are what we're focusing on every three years. So we review those when we prepare each long-term plan. Below that is all the key strategies and plans. And then we've also got internal strategic priorities that are reviewed every year. And then  Below that are kind of the mechanisms that give effect to all that. So things like the long-term plan, the district plan, yeah, our JMAs, those kinds of things. All right, so in terms of the long-term plan, we already have one. This is our current one for 2018 to 2028. We're currently reviewing that to have a new one for 2021 to 2031. So I'm sure a lot of you are familiar with this already, but I'll give a bit more detail about the long-term plan and what it is. So its purpose is simply to describe the community outcomes that council is looking to achieve, detail all the activities and services that we are providing to give effect to those community outcomes and visions. It seeks to give a long-term focus. So yeah, it's got all the projects that we're gonna be involved in for the next 10 years.  But it's also got longer term thinking in there in terms of the infrastructure strategy. So this is when all the budget managers work together, figure out what projects we need to put in there to give effect to the vision, and look for ways that they can dovetail on each other so that there's a sort of efficiency. So if there's a project happening in a certain space, it would be good for, say, the roadie manager and the parks manager to both be across where that's happening and when,  and see if they can deliver it in more of an efficient way. And of course, the long-term plan is a key kind of document that gives accountability, that the community can use to see accountability from the council. So it says what we're going to do, and it gets checked in, and they can use that to see if council has actually done what it says it's going to do. So in terms of the planning cycle, I mentioned  Previously, the long-term plan gets reviewed every three years. In between that three-year cycle, there's an annual plan that's prepared. And if we're significantly deviating from what's in the long-term plan, then there'll be a consultation process. It recognized that the current one is quite ambitious. There's a lot of work going on to try and account for all the growth, putting in core infrastructure, and it's quite a full LTP.  So the agreed approach was essentially to carry that over for the next three years as much as possible. Of course, there'll be new things coming in as they always do, but in essence, try and just carry over the current LTP as much as possible and try and set ourselves up to develop that transformational LTP in 2024. So with that in mind, we have agreed with elected members to maintain the current levels of service. So everything council does in terms of running its libraries,  looking after the roads and water. We've agreed to try and deliver the services at the same level. So they shouldn't be delivered to a higher level or a lower level, just continue with the current levels of service. We've engaged with the community on the vision, the community outcomes and those priorities. And I'll talk to that a bit more shortly. And we're also currently attending Hui with Mana Whenua throughout the district. Yeah.  So in terms of engaging with the community on the vision, the community outcomes and the strategic priorities, we've we've primarily done that through a series of neighborhood barbecues throughout the district. So there were there were six scheduled, but unfortunately,  Two of them got impacted by the COVID pandemic, and we couldn't have the one that was scheduled to happen at Ohaupo or the one for the balloons over Waipa event. But we did hand out thousands of sausages through those events and a lot of survey forms to try and garner the community's feedback on what their aspirations are for the district and what they want council to focus on in the coming years. And we've used that to reframe our vision, our community outcomes,  and our priorities so that we can set ourselves up to try and deliver those. So yeah, lots of great discussions at those barbecues, but we also did an online survey to try and contact more people outside of the barbecues, and we received feedback online from them. So yeah, we took all their responses, packaged it up, and used that to inform some decision-making.  And what did we hear on the vision? So in terms of the current vision for WIPA, Home of Champions, Building the Future Together. I hate it. Generally, what we found out was that the vast majority of people either liked it or loved it. So 28% of people loved it and 38% of people liked it. Yeah, just a small minority of people hated it at 4%.  So with that in mind, we had a pretty clear idea that we were on the right track with our vision. In terms of the community outcomes, the next layer down. So there's been amendment to the LGA, which has reintroduced well-being and the four well-being domains back into the act, being cultural, environmental, economic, and social well-being. And we've heard what that means for our communities.  we also heard back from our communities on what they would like us to focus on for the next sort of three years. So we got feedback, not just from those barbecues, but also we undertook some targeted stakeholder engagement. So in terms of the community feedback, the focus areas were building vibrant communities, promoting the use of te reo in our communities, attracting domestic and international visitors, and preparing for climate change.  And in terms of the more targeted stakeholder feedback, where we engage with groups directly, we heard from them that promoting connections and health via physical infrastructure was important, that sustainable resource use is important, developing a vision for culture and heritage in the district is important, and that retail and Main Street survival was important.  So that last one there just highlights the fact that that stakeholder engagement happened after the pandemic. So at the forefront of people's minds was the need to how we're going to get through this pandemic and recover economically. So we've taken all that feedback and tested it with our leadership team and our elected members. And where we've landed is not having wholesale changes to our vision or community outcomes,  but just some tweaks to try and clarify a few things. So I'll just run you through where we've got to now.  So now our current vision is Waipa, home of champions, building connected communities. So that kind of picks up on the fact that a lot of what we heard back was about building connections and being collaborative and taking more of a facilitative approach to try and deliver all of the things council needs to do. So we've tried to build that into our vision with the word connected there. In terms of the community outcomes, that next layer down,  We've kind of mirrored the Local Government Act, really, and we've got cultural champions, socially resilient, environmental champions, and economically progressive. And from the feedback we've got on our priority areas for the next three years, we've got creating vibrant communities, leading the recovery of Waipā, nurturing and respecting our unique culture and heritage,  effectively planning and providing for growing communities and preparing for climate change.
